Issues.Title: Fix DataGridColumn default property
Issues.Body:
Best reviewed commit-by-commit

Fixes #101
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix DataGridColumn default property" (#884)

Issues.Title: Add CommonDialog tests, cleanup CommonDialog, and Fix Debug assert in Control.GetSafeHandle
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add CommonDialog tests, cleanup CommonDialog, and Fix Debug assert in Control.GetSafeHandle" (#880)

Issues.Title: Setting new DataGridColumnStyle().NullText to null unnecessarily invalidates
Issues.Body:
Also calls `OnNullTextChanged` even if nothing

E.g.
```cs
var style = new DataGridBoolColumn();
style.NullText = null;

style.NullText = null; // Invalidates again...
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Setting new DataGridColumnStyle().NullText to null unnecessarily invalidates" (#894)

Issues.Title: Add FileDialog tests, cleanup FileDialog and remove dead FileDialog code
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add FileDialog tests, cleanup FileDialog and remove dead FileDialog code" (#893)

Issues.Title: Some editors missing
Issues.Body: I can't see System.Drawing.Design.FontNameEditor and System.ComponentModel.Design.MultilineStringEditor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Some editors missing" (#892)

Issues.Title: WinForms should test for binary serialization
Issues.Body:
Once you decide which types need to remain serializable #889 you need to test the remaining types for binary serialization.

These types should be tested to ensure they are serializable today, remain serializable in the future, and that they can round-trip to desktop.

Tests will likely involve consuming in binary payloads in test data and consuming this in tests.  You'll also likely want to annotate members that are forzen for serialization purposes.  @ViktorHofer did a lot of this work for CoreFx and may be able to provide some pointers.

This work should be semi-parallelizable with #889 since you know you have some types already that need to stay Serializable (EG: ImageList).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms should test for binary serialization" (#890)

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Forms should reduce the number of types that use SerializableAttribute
Issues.Body:
Not all types that were Serializable in desktop need to be serializable in .NETCore.  Maintaining SerializableAttribute on types means those types need to be tested for Version to Version serialization and potentially framework-to-framework serialization.  This makes it harder to evolve those types and can be costly to maintain.

We've started looking at types that require Serializable for resource scenarios.  Those must be in.

There are likley some types that the designer needs to be serializable, but those may or may not require binary serialization.  As much as you can you should try to avoid depending on binary serialization for internal only scenarios since it increases the maintainence cost of the public types.

Of the remaining types you need to audit their serialization scenarios and look at usage data.  Previously @ViktorHofer worked on this.  I believe they got some help from @marklio to analyze usage by looking at types marked as serializable and the sorts of fields they might contain.  You might be able to convince them to rerun this analysis and include WinForms assemblies.

Once you decide which ones to remove you can just remove the attribute and test.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Windows.Forms should reduce the number of types that use SerializableAttribute" (#889)

Issues.Title: System.Design name space is missing resources in core.
Issues.Body: Source of System.Design.dll is ported but not all resources are ported.  Also, we may need to port only .ico formats if they were not already and update System.Design source code to use .ico formats from winforms assembly wherever it was earlier referencing .bmp formats
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Design name space is missing resources in core." (#888)

Issues.Title: An error pops up when using the property DefaultCellStyle of DataGridView in the .NET Core 3.0 winforms application
Issues.Body:
**OS:** RS5 X64
**VS:** Visual Studio 2019 Version 16.1.0 Preview 3.0 [28824.157.d16.0]
**.NET SDK:** .NET Core 3.0.100-preview5-011555 from release branch
**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:** No
**More Info:** 
1. The repro video: \\\mlangfs1\public\Winforms\v-jiaol\bug\DataGridVew\Call with DataGridViewDefaultCellStyleIssueRepro.mp4

**Steps to Reproduce:** 
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application by command: dotnet new winforms –o “xxx”.
2. Write code to Form1.cs.
   DataGridView dgv = new DataGridView();;
           DataGridViewCellStyle style = new DataGridViewCellStyle();
           style.BackColor = Color.Red;
           dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle = style;
3. Insert an breakpoint in this code: dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle = style; and debug the application.

**Actual:** 
When debugging to dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle= style;, the exception pops up.
![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49627022/56728615-cda58980-6785-11e9-8851-03258fe4ff7d.png)




**Call Stack:** 
 System.NullReferenceException
  HResult=0x80004003
  Message=Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
  Source=System.Windows.Forms
  StackTrace:
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewBand.set_DefaultCellStyle(DataGridViewCellStyle value)
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.set_DefaultCellStyle(DataGridViewCellStyle value)
   at WindowsFormsApp2.Form1..ctor() in C:\Users\v-jiaol\source\repos\WindowsFormsApp2\WindowsFormsApp2\Form1.cs:line 22
   at WindowsFormsApp2.Program.Main() in C:\Users\v-jiaol\source\repos\WindowsFormsApp2\WindowsFormsApp2\Program.cs:line 19


**Expected:** 
No exception pops up, application runs successfully.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "An error pops up when using the property DefaultCellStyle of DataGridView in the .NET Core 3.0 winforms application" (#879)

Issues.Title: WebBrowser Control Printing API Suggestions
Issues.Body:
I have used the WebBrowser control in WinForms applications to display/print simple(ish) HTML reports generated dynamically using XSLT. In my experience, this has proven to be a lighter-weight/more accessible solution than using the ReportViewerControl (last I checked the ReportViewerControl was not that accessible to screen readers like JAWS).

One of my requirements is to print reports (HTML) sequentially in batch using user selected print settings. The current WebBrowser control print methods do not make this particularly easy. (Admittedly, this may not be a use case for which the WebBrowser control was originally intended).

The [ShowPrintDialog()](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.webbrowser.showprintdialog?view=netframework-4.8) method does not return user selected print settings like [PrintDialog.PrinterSettings](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.printdialog.printersettings?view=netframework-4.8) does. The WebBrowser control [Print()](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.webbrowser.print?view=netframework-4.8) method always uses the current print and page settings.

It would be useful to have a Print overload that took something along the lines of PrinterSettings as an argument if possible.

```csharp
public void Print(PrinterSettings settings);  // perhaps print to a non-default printer
```

It also might be useful to directly expose the PrintTemplateTeardown event to be able to easily determine when printing has completed.

Another somewhat related (maybe less feasible) idea I had would be to expose a PrintPdf() function which could use feature detection to determine if the Win10 Print to PDF Driver is available. If so, print using that driver, if not, throw PNSE.

```csharp
public void PrintPdf(string filename);
public void PrintPdf(string filename, PrinterSettings settings);
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WebBrowser Control Printing API Suggestions" (#873)

Issues.Title: Replacing getting hash codes from ComboBox items with generating IDs for items
Issues.Body:
There is an issue #869 with objects which have intentionally overridden GetHashCode() method which may throw an exception. So Hashtable and Dictionary cannot be used as a storage for collection of accessible objects keyed by items.

The current fix replaces getting hash code from the very item with generating ID for the item using ObjectIDGenerator API (reference equal is used to compare underlying objects instead of the hash code).
Here are more info and example: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/470114/objectidgenerator-vs-hashsett 

Also fixed RuntimeId getting for the item.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Replacing getting hash codes from ComboBox items with generating IDs for items" (#870)

Issues.Title: ComboBox cannot accept items with not implemented GetHashCode method
Issues.Body:
**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create WinForms app with ComboBox control.
2. Implement Class1 class and override its GetHashCode() method to throw Exception in the method body.
3. Add an instance of Class1 to the list of ComboBox control items.
4. Run the app.

**Actual:** there is an Exception thrown when working with the form with ComboBox.
**Expected:** there should be no exception.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ComboBox cannot accept items with not implemented GetHashCode method" (#869)

Issues.Title: [.Net Core]The icons still show the gear icon
Issues.Body:
**OS**: RS4 X64
**VS**: Dev16 16.1 d16.1 branch 28823.117 build
**.NET Core**: 3.0.100-preview5-11552 from Release branch

**More Info:**
1. This issue not reproduce .NET Framework project.
2. Affect controls and these's dependence dll.

Controls | DLL | Repositories
-- | -- | --
FileSystemWatcher | System.IO.FileSystem.Watcher.dll | dotnet/Corefx
PerformanceCounter | System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.dll | dotnet/Corefx
Process | System.Diagnostics.Process.dll | dotnet/Corefx
SerialPort | System.IO.Ports.dll | dotnet/Corefx
ServiceController | System.ServiceProcess.ServiceController.dll | dotnet/Corefx
PrintDocument | System.Drawing.Common.dll | dotnet/Corefx
DataSet | System.Data.Common.dll | dotnet/Corefx
BackgroundWorker | System.ComponentModel.EventBasedAsync.dll | dotnet/Corefx
DirectoryEntry | System.DirectoryServices.dll | dotnet/Corefx
DirectorySearcher | System.DirectoryServices.dll | dotnet/Corefx
EventLog | System.Diagnostics.EventLog.dll | dotnet/Corefx




**Steps to reproduce:**
 1. Install the .NET Core 3.0 SDK from https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk for Release branch.
 2. Open the .NET Core app from \\\mlangfs1\public\Winforms\CoreTest\IconChange\4.22\Issue1.zip  in VS.
 3. Run it and observe the control icon such as FileSystemWatcher

**Actual:**  FileSystemWatcher icon show gear
![FileSystemWatcher](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49627041/56650382-7df98c00-66b9-11e9-8233-d206e640cd4d.PNG)

**Expected:** FileSystemWatcher can show it's own icon.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[.Net Core]The icons still show the gear icon" (#866)
